Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: MARK JEMIMA BROWN RIDGE

Present Address: Christian Rest Home Smithville Burnaby 3801

Pioneer Address: Oakshole Saskatchewan

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1890. Our first address was Broadview.

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Several there was a good neighborly spirit. How many of these were bachelor's homes? One.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? No regular time, but there was a friendly spirit in the community.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? We saw the neighbors at church and had a friendly chat going home with each other to supper.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Both going when invited or not always welcome.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Every old time as the occasion required, the young people often went to each other's homes by invitation and had a meal.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

Yes.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? The term (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

Was there any friend would be hurt if you did not stay? It was expected of you if you looked for your neighbor to return the visit.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? More than just a good meal was served; just such things as you had in the house.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the plants? All went till the children were grown then they went to the garden.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Some times a few women would come to help quilt; thrashing was the usual gathering.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

Thrashing time was the most common when twenty-five men gathered, a neighbor woman would come in to help with the cooking and make lunch for the men.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. In the early thirty a new brick school was built in the Edgewood district and for some years social dances were held in the school or whist drives and dances, but since the war have been discontinued.

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

More since the war.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

The young people's society at the church had a social once a month and often had little parties from house to house.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box suppers, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

After the Bethel church was closed, the new Edgewood school was built in 1926. There was social dancing in the new school, whist drives, dances, or Christmas parties. There was an organ in the school for music.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

The social life now centered around the school for a few years. After the war began, there were more social affairs in the school, but school concerts still continued. One year about 1928, the Edgewood school won...

9. When was your first community hall built? How large was it?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? In some cases.

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? There was a stable at the school and a shed at the church.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Whist, cribbage, five hundred.

Was there card playing for a prize? There were prizes given for the highest score and a lucky prize for the lowest score and a traveling prize.

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. When the social gatherings were under the church, there was no dancing or cards. Whist was often played, all gave in. When the gatherings were under the school, there were indulged in - all agreed there was never any trouble.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for recreation purposes, how social and other activities (Christian also) were conducted there. (Describe.)

9. How much of your normal life was centered around the schools, and within the school district? Describe. Why did you continue to use the local school building even after the new school opened?

10. What was your first community hall built for? Who built it? How large was it? How was it used? What materials was it made of? Who paid for it? How was it paid for? Who paid for it? How was it paid for?

11. What kind of games were popular in the early days? What kind of games were popular in the later years? What kind of games were popular in the present day?

12. Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

13. Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it? Why? What kind of gatherings were under the church? Were they more or less formal than those held elsewhere? How often were they held? How many attended each time?
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?
   Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Small social gatherings were very popular from house to house. Many different games were played such as animal or vegetable crinoline, charades & stunts were indulged in.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc. that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

These small parties were popular as early as 1890, there would be a social time of games & singing till eleven o'clock when a supper would be served when the table would be laid, later a lunch would be handed around & tea this would consist of sandwiches & cake. This is some years later.

   The Edmonton League of Christian Endeavor 1905.
   Give the date and reason for it being organized. 1905 To provide interest for the young people now growing up in the district.

22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? The winters of 1908-9, 1909-10, the young people built skating rinks near the Bethel Church. Skating was enjoyed.

What games were played indoors in winter? Card games such as "Happy Families," "Authors" or other card games or other games? The game of "Linch" was quite popular for several winters from 1908-9 to 1909-10.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

The young people and parents too where they were not too old.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

Everyone was too busy with the farmwork for games in its day.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

During the Boar war they built snow forts & played at war. My son & his companions had an old stable fortified with sticks through holes to represent guns.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

August 1903.

26. Who organized it? The Billington school. Everyone welcome.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? It was gotten up by the Billington school but all were welcome from far & near.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? I do not think so.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? Children races & ball games.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

Tables were laid & the lunches all put together & all ate at the table. All provided free. Later small groups ate together.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Sandwiches cake & pie, ice cream.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

Started shortly after one o'clock & lasted till seven or eight o'clock. Many people coming from the town of Grenfell & Broadview.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

The people just had a social time meeting people they knew from other districts or getting acquainted. There were people from the towns of Grenfell & Broadview, many that we only met at picnic time. A good time was had by all.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

People were not so social. Private groups kept by themselves or ate in separate groups.

People now make social picnics more enjoyable by themselves or in separate groups.

   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

   There was no sports day in our district—but the thirty-fourth of May was Grenfell Sports Day for years.

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

   The Bible was the only book I brought. In 1891 my brother G.B. Buckin Toronto sent me a copy of Ben Hur by Lew Wallace which I enjoyed very much and read several times.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

   We did exchange books of a religious nature such as "A Christian secret of a happy life."

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

   There was no money to spare for books. The young people read the Elsie Books, the Pansie Books, Leather stocking tails such as the Last of the Mohicans.

   What kind of books and how many?

   We did exchange books of a religious nature such as
   "Christian Science Quarterly" and "Christian Science Monitor".

There was no money to buy books. The young
people read the Bible and the Pioneer Books by Nathan
Steele.

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? There has been for many years a good library in the town of Grenfell. When was it started? Who started it?

Is it still in existence? Yes.

If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

The library in the Bethel Church was much read by young & old. When the church was closed some of the best books were given to the Grenfell town library, such as the life of Dwight L. Moody, Sunday the true Sabbath, Patriarchs & Prophets.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

We took the Hamilton Spectator for years, and the Northern Advocate for the children, also the Family Herald or weekly Star from Montreal.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

Later we took a Winnipeg paper that I have forgotten the name of also the Regina Leader.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? We got the Aberdeen literature it was sent to me.

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

By mail, in the 1890s - as near as I can remember we read it & passed it on to the neighbors.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

The only one the Bible.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

We certainly missed the Ontario literature at first but it was not long till we were able to get literature so surely did appreciate the Aberdeen literature.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so, when was it started?
   In 1931, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   We took the Hamilton Evening Tribune for years, and the Northam Tribune for the children also the family.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain ones and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   Yes, we got the Aberdeen literature if we as adults were interested.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   The only one the Bible

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

We certainly missed the Canadian literature at first, but it was not long before we were able to get Canadian newspapers and subscribed to the Aberdeen literature.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?
The violin.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? None in the early days.
For the ministry homes began to get organs. We got an organ in 1895.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
We bought our organ in 1895 of Mr. Davis of Greenfield. We bought the church organ of him which he gave us at a reduced rate.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
Groups of young people gathered in our home specially on Sunday evenings or a singsong was indulged in in the community? (Were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.
Just informal gatherings not planned or invited, just stopping in & sang hymns.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?
The only singing I remember was hymnal songs in the community?
